Two part question.

1. How much should I expect to pay per video to work with an agency creating YouTube videos optimized for SEO? I ideally see these videos being 5-7 minutes long, in person, and well produced (i.e., professional lighting, quality sound, professional editing). 
2. Does anyone have recommendations for video agencies?

elements.text: Two part question.

How much should I expect to pay per video to work with an agency creating YouTube videos optimized for SEO? I ideally see these videos being 5-7 minutes long, in person, and well produced (i.e., professional lighting, quality sound, professional editing).
Does anyone have recommendations for video agencies?

text:
My company does motion design videos, but we work with a lot of video production companies.
For something with good production value, I'd say you could expect to pay something like 10–20k per video depending on the complexity. If the series of videos are all similar (One location, same talent, same shoot day) that will help reduce the overall cost.

elements.text:

text: `1` entirely depends on your scope, the agency, and their rates. (It’s a riff on the ‘how long is a piece of string’ question — you won’t know until you measure.)

text: Biggest thing for SEO is clicks, watch time and session time. The titles and descriptions help, but less so than those other pieces. Are you going to get them done animated? or something like <https://www.colossyan.com/colossyan-studio|Colossyan>?

text:
Hey everyone! I’d like to source some wisdom from the crowd *re: content strategy for an early-stage startup*…

:question: _TL;DR - Here’s my question_
*Is prioritizing the creation & distribution of TOFU, well-thought-out TL pieces the right way to start?*

My line of thinking is that by doing so, we can increase brand awareness & get traction around the keywords/phrases we’ll eventually target.

If we were to tackle MOFU/BOFU right off the bat, I feel our efforts may be less impactful as we’re just not on the radar yet (company nor products).

:information_source: _Full context_
*We* *currently have* *no direct competitors & no keywords / SEO juice surrounding our products*. (Treading lightly on my verbiage here… When I say “no keywords / SEO juice,” I mean we’re kind of paving the way in the industry for a new product. There is some traction around less competitive, long-tail keywords, but we have yet to squeeze our way into those conversations and results.)

Plus, *we’re starting all content efforts from scratch.* So, we have no internal assets to benchmark off of.

Traditionally, attacking MOFU/BOFU content first to target those with higher search intent is common practice, but people aren’t searching for our product… Nor do they know we exist, what problems we solve, etc.

*Any and all feedback is welcome! TIA* :pray::skin-tone-4:

If we were to tackle MOFU/BOFU right off the bat, I feel our efforts may be less impactful as we’re just not on the radar yet (company nor products).

. (Treading lightly on my verbiage here… When I say “no keywords / SEO juice,” I mean we’re kind of paving the way in the industry for a new product. There is some traction around less competitive, long-tail keywords, but we have yet to squeeze our way into those conversations and results.)

Plus,
we’re starting all content efforts from scratch.

So, we have no internal assets to benchmark off of.

Traditionally, attacking MOFU/BOFU content first to target those with higher search intent is common practice, but people aren’t searching for our product… Nor do they know we exist, what problems we solve, etc.
Any and all feedback is welcome! TIA

text: From our very own <@UJG9WTEKG> <https://www.animalz.co/blog/bottom-of-the-funnel-thought-leadership/> :raised_hands:

elements.text: From our very own

text: Also: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/movement-first/>

elements.text: Also:

text:
Since you have a new product and no name recognition, you need to give people a reason to listen to you. What is your unique perspective on your market? Hone that first, and then hammer it home in your content. Over time, people in your market will associate that perspective with your brand, and you will start to build an audience.

That said, don’t outright ignore SEO now, either. The benefits of SEO are compounding, and the earlier you can start to lay a solid foundation, the sooner you’ll see results.

elements.text:
Since you have a new product and no name recognition, you need to give people a reason to listen to you. What is your unique perspective on your market? Hone that first, and then hammer it home in your content. Over time, people in your market will associate that perspective with your brand, and you will start to build an audience.

That said, don’t outright ignore SEO now, either. The benefits of SEO are compounding, and the earlier you can start to lay a solid foundation, the sooner you’ll see results.

text: <@U01L7S9CVNG> That would be ideal if possible. But I know sometimes top-of-funnel thought leadership doesn’t perfectly align with the less-competitive long-tail SEO keywords you want to tackle first. In that case, I’d do both in parallel. Build up your TOFU TL *and* start laying your SEO content foundation.

and
start laying your SEO content foundation.

text:
Hey there Superpath! I just started a new role as Content Manager at a startup that focuses on helping financial advisors offer estate planning services to their clients. We've identified education as a huge area of need for the business, and we're exploring the possibility of investing in online courses as our primary content initiative. This is totally new territory for me, so I thought I'd stop by here and ask:

*If your brand has a major focus on online courses:* 
• *What does your team structure look like? (# of people, roles & responsibilities)*
• *What do you outsource to an agency or freelancers vs. keeping in house?* 
• *What does your tech stack look like?*

text: We're doing this at the moment and 100% agree with <@U01KH3P18RZ>. You can do reasonably effective person-talking-to-camera video with some interstitial images and effects quite cheaply. But I've had a month or so of trial and error figuring out what to outsource, what our standards are vis-a-vis our budget, etc.

text: I agree with Colin that doing both in parallel if possible is the most ideal. The trap that most startups fall into is focusing on TOFU at the expense of everything else to generate “buzz” and have nothing to move potential customers through an actual buying process. What’s the point of attracting eyeballs if those eyeballs don’t eventually convert into paying customers?

elements.text: I agree with Colin that doing both in parallel if possible is the most ideal. text: I think advertising is more effective for consumer products that are simple and low-cost. Getting a message or a product info to as many people as possible. Content marketing is more about building credibility and authority with a specific audience segment. Content marketing is soft sell, ads are hard sell.

elements.text: I think advertising is more effective for consumer products that are simple and low-cost. Getting a message or a product info to as many people as possible. Content marketing is more about building credibility and authority with a specific audience segment. Content marketing is soft sell, ads are hard sell.

text:
I'm going to come at it slightly differently <@U01L7S9CVNG>. I prefer starting with content pieces that are closest to revenue.

But I would also want to understand the actual buying journey/path to purchase - capturing all the buying triggers.

Once you know that - you can see the natural gaps in your content.
